Okay, you have the one novel and a lot of short stories. I know you're working. I've seen your force that you're working on forthcoming novels, but are you more comfortable with the short story? Oh, yeah. Yeah, I'm a short story writer. I, the only reason I'm writing, there are two reasons I'm writing them bones and novel one is I should have written it. I got the idea for it in 1970, like when I first started writing and it bothered me for 12 years. The idea bothered me for 12 years to write it. So that's why I'm writing them bones again. But otherwise I'd just be writing short stories and not making a living, you know, like everybody else. Do you, do you write full time? segments.text: Kind of how you grew up and what might influence your right science fiction or to write in general and why science fiction in particular?
Well, I started reading this stuff when I was six years old. Like, you know, most people start sometime before they're twelve.
I started when I was six and actually the first book I read was really amazing. It was Chad Oliver's Mists of Dawn in the old Winston edition, you know.
And I'll never forget that book and you know, and it's real wonderful. Now I'm a friend of Chad, you know, here thirty years later and stuff like never, never thought.
But I grew up reading this stuff when I was a kid and then in the early sixties, I got into through Buddy Saunders.
I got into comic book fandom, which was just starting up like in, but it was like one of the four people in the world who have copies of Rockets Blast comic collector from number one,
which was put out on carbon paper to the four people who subscribe to it or something.
But Buddy got me into comic book fandom originally as an artist. Originally did art. I did like covers for fanzines and you know,
how Buddy and the Art like inked his artwork and stuff like that and started writing. Since I've been reading science fiction all along,
I wrote essentially what is George Martin and everybody referred to back then as text stories, which were the printed stories like you would see in the fanzines and stuff of the time.
Printed stories of like about the comic book characters, except they were written instead of you know, in panel form, they were written out.
And from there, it was just like by the mid sixties, I was writing SF stories and submitting them and getting them back and you know, doing that until I finally sold.
Oh, I'm sorry.
Don't go ahead.
The science fiction aspect and why not westerns or fantasy or romance or something. Why was it science fiction?
Well, because I'd grown up reading it, you know, and I'd gotten away from reading. It's amazing. I'd gotten away from reading while I was writing the stories.
As I went away from reading science fiction, there was a period about three years there where mostly while I was reading, I was in college and I was in theater and journalism,
things like that. I was reading plays and movie scripts and novels and things like that instead of, you know, regular novels instead of SF.
And but I was still writing the SF because I mean, it was there since I was six years old, you know, and it just stays with you.
And that's that's essentially what, well, actually, if you want to know, everybody has a story like this, but I read Lynn Carter's Wizards of Lemuria.
And I said, if he can get that published, I can write, I can get that, you know, I can get my stuff published.
It's, you know, it's real obvious. Like, I mean, everybody, I think has a story about that. They read something after they've been reading this stuff for 20 years.
They finally read something that just pushes their buttons and says, that's garbage, you know, and I can write better than that.
Even when you're 18 years old, you say, I can write better than that. And you set out to prove it.
And a lot of people set out to prove it, write a story and like submitted or don't submit it, just write the story to prove it.
They can write a story, you know, not even writing a story.
So essentially is I got serious about this about submitting it and things like that, you know, and did.
That's why I accept.
I like to ask this question of people that are roughly my age. I'm 34 and the Sputnik and that fallout had a lot of effect on me and what I did when I became an old man.
Did that have any influence on you because science was really something back in the 50s and they really pushed it?
Well, the only surprise was, I mean, if you're talking about the effect like Stephen King talks about in Dance Macabre,
he was watching Earth versus the Flying Saucers and the theater manager came out and said the Russians have put up a satellite and the theater goes,
you know, and everybody was stunned. I wasn't stunned at all.
I mean, Phil Palsett, farmer always says, I got turned off in science fiction when we weren't on the moon by 1949.
You know, I haven't respected science since then because he grew up as a kid to 30s, you know, always expecting us to be on the moon by 1949.
But I mean, I had, you know, I was in the 50s, I was a space freak and a jet plane freak, you know, and call it model airplanes and model spaceships and things like that.
The only surprise was that the Russians actually did it first because we had, you know, said we were going ahead and doing it in 56 and getting serious about it.
It was just that they'd gotten a little serious, a little faster, you know, and then we spent the next three years trying to essentially catch up, you know, and top them.
But I mean, it was no surprise to me. It was good because I thought I would be one of the first people on Mars.
Essentially, you know, you think when like when Sputnik goes up and you're, you know, you're 13 years old, you know, you say, well, good, then there'll be an astronaut training.
I mean, there'll be a space man, space man training program and I'll get in the space man training and we'll be on Mars by 1970, you know, and stuff like that.
But that that was the good aspect of it.

And then like as if you read Tom Wolf's right stuff or talking about, you know, these guys that flew these, you know, everybody thought that we would have the three step rocket in the space station the whole bit.

Everybody that flew the experimental rocket planes and jets thought the guys going to the astronaut program were nuts, you know, because they said, what, get in a can and ride it up and go around and come back down and don't fly it or anything.
You know, I mean, they thought that was just garbage, you know, and nobody knew that's the way it was going to be.
You know, they had the dinosaur project on it, which really, you know, essentially like the shuttle is now, you know, and we thought it'd be like that.
You would fly the thing up and you would fly it back in and you would land it, you know, and things like that and use it over and over and stuff.

But I assumed that I would be one of the, you know, like when you're a kid that hot about stuff, you assume you'll be one of the first people on Mars or, you know, stuff like that, you know, that's what did.
I mean, it just made me, you know, say, well, good, it's going to happen, you know.
Okay.
Lunchbox, as I understand it, was your first published story. How many heads you've written and how easy was it or difficult was it to break in finally to publish?
Well, essentially, I had been, I had been trying to get published since 1966, been serious about it, 65 and 66.
And I'd been publishing in fanzines all along, stories in fanzines.
And I just kept sending the stories out until finally one of them sold.
I mean, there was no, there was no problem breaking in as such.
I mean, it wasn't like a conscious thing saying this is the one I'm going to break in with or I'm going to write a story to break in.
It was just I'd been sending them out and getting them back until one day I sent one out and it didn't come back, you know, Chad came back.
That's, you know, it was like I'd been, I'd been writing for fanzines all along in comic scripts and things like that.
And the, the story just came, I mean, when it was time for it to sell, it's sold, you know.
Okay. Was lunchbox, by the way, did that precede the Viking lander?
In fact, it was, I sold that story in 1969 or not in 69 and 70.
And I sold it four days or I got the letter four days after I was drafted in the army.
And but because John Kimmel, it was sold analog because John Kimmel died in the meantime and everything was in and uproar at Street Smith for four days.
About, or Condon asked for six months or so.
Ben Bova wrote me a letter in 1972 and said, I'm changing all, originally it was called Voyager.
If you remember the Viking, the Viking stuff is all called Voyager.
And the whole story was talking about the Voyager lander and all this kind of stuff.
And Ben Bova wrote and says, is it okay if I change, change Voyager to Viking so you won't look like a jerk?
And I said, why sure, Ben? You know, anything you want.
And, you know, because the technology had changed the, it changed the term, you know, the terminology in the meantime.
And, you know, I'd been in the army and what was that?
You know, I was guarding PX's and stuff, you know, and I, you know, I hadn't been kept up on the change in terminology in the meantime, you know.
But yes, it was, it preceded.
There were, there were several prototype models of the essentially what became the Viking lander all competing for, for the contract in the late 60s.
And the Voyager thing was one of them.

And I've got a, I've got a picture I visited Langley for one of the mock-ups of the, of the original Voyager thing, which was slightly, it looked much the same as the Viking eventually was, but had, you know, longer arm and all this kind of stuff, you know.
But anyway, yeah, it, it preceded the program.
So that's why, you know, the change to Viking was, you know, like fitted into the story, you know.
What, a story of yours that affected me maybe surprisingly much when I read everything was, was Mono no aware, Mono no aware?
Mono no wario.
Wario, I believe is the way the Japanese pronounce it.
I figured it's hard for Texans to pronounce Japanese.
Yeah.
That one where it works, talking about except the past is inevitable, that sort of thing.
That one.
How did, how did, how did that hit you?
Well, this story was one of the easiest stories I ever wrote in my life.
It's amazing.
It like, it came to me one afternoon and I had it finished by like eight o'clock at night and send it off and sold it.
You know, I sent it off to a couple or three, four places first, which rejected, of course.
But it was finally published in Haunt of Horror, the short live Marvel science fiction magazine.
But no, I was just doing, I was reading the Hiroshima, you know, about Hiroshima.
I'd always been interested in, but you know, the atomic, the atomic bomb in, in, in the fact of the atomic bomb, we grew up with it, you know, and stuff like that.
And to, to a lot of people, they sort of, they sort of, they sort of forgot for a while what it was all about and everything.
And I think that Japan is the only nation in the world that has experienced an atomic war.
I mean, it's, you know, that's it.
They're, they're the only ones.

And I was reading all this research and there are several books like the Flowers of Hiroshima and things like that, which, which had been written about the survivors and about the, about things like that.
So Ed Bryant did a story later called the Hippokusha Gallery, or at about the same time, in fact, although it wasn't published too much later.

But there's a fascination with, there was a fascination with, with, with the fact of the bomb and Monon, Mononowari, I was reading about Mononowari, the feeling, it's a, it's a, it's a, it's sort of almost indescribable.
They usually describe it as the sadness of the beauty of the world.
You know, it's like the translation of it about the transience of things and stuff like that.
And it's a, it's a Japanese and it's, it's not a Zen term, but it's almost a, it's almost, it's sort of an alien term to Westerners and stuff.
And Donald Ritchie wrote a series of articles on that feeling in Japanese films, which I just read at the time.

And those influence me, it all just came together, you know, the whole thing about trying to stop the inoligate from dropping the bomb, you know, and like the futility of, of changing it, you know, and because it happened, I mean, even the guy does change things.
He doesn't change that. He doesn't change the fact.

And it really, it, it came to me, like I said, it came to me all at once and I wrote it and tried to get that feeling into the story, the, the feeling that the Japanese were talking about in the story.
And I don't know if I did it, but it worked for me. You know, it worked for me when I wrote the story.
It's thought it was very effective.
Okay, I want to move on. A lot of the stuff you did in the 70s was a collaborative effort with Stephen Utley, with Buddy Saunders, and one of George Martin.
How, how do you collaborate and why did you choose this as a way of writing?
Well, it shows us what happened. It was the Turkey City writers, which had come to be referred as because of Turkey's Turkey City writers workshops.
We, there was a group of us and we all, it's, it's, it's amazing that it happened.
We're all from, we're all from Texas living in Texas and we all published our first story within like six or eight months of each other. It was amazing.
It just happened that way. And we all got, got, got to meet each other at conventions within like six months of our first story is being published.
And we were all writing at the same time. We're all serious about this stuff. We're going to take over.
And one of the ways we did it was we started collaborating with each other and we've do stories on our own, but then we'd also do stories that we couldn't do on our own with the other people.
And it wasn't a conscious effort on anybody's part. I think it just one of those things that just happened, you know, like the Futurians all living in the same apartment.
That just happened, you know, and like, I mean, you know, all this kind of stuff. It just happened.
And we wrote for a period of about the thing about the collaboration with Steve is although they've been appearing up until two years ago, nearly all of them were written between 1972 and 1975.
Like I haven't done but about two collaborations since 1975. It's just that the publishing schedules, you know, are delayed and they like come out later and stuff like that.
And people think that they were just done six months ago, but they weren't. But most of our collaborations of all those people were over by about 75 or 76.
And it's just one of those things that happened. You know, we were just all writing at the same time. We're all right there.
Like buddy was my landlord, you know, he owned one half a duplex and I was any other. And he, of course, he got me into comics fandom 10 years before that anyway.

And some of us were friends. Some of us met each other and became friends and things like that. And it's just that we just we just sparked each other, you know, if you if you had something you were doing and you got through with it and you weren't quite ready to do something else.
You could always, you know, do a collaboration with buddy or with with Proctor or with, you know, you know, anything like that.

And like we just there must have been in space about two years, there must have been 35 or 40 stories come out of the various collaborations, you know, to and sometimes three way collaborations with people, you know, it was amazing.
And it's amazing that it happened and it's amazing that we got so much done on our own too, besides doing all that, you know.

It was just a stroke of luck.
